qas.question: When was ASCII first commercially used?

answers.text: a seven-bit teleprinter code for American Telephone & Telegraph's TWX (TeletypeWriter eXchange) network

qas.question: What did TWX use before ASCII?
Who is the father of ASCII?
What was the code first called in Europe?
When was ASCII first used by Berner-Ross?
What did TWX use because to counter slow loading times of ASCII?
What was the TWX first called in Europe?
Who competed against eight-bit teleprinter code?

context: ASCII itself was first used commercially during <a0_0><b5_0>1963<b5_0/><a0_0/> as <a1_0>a seven-bit teleprinter code for American Telephone & Telegraph's TWX (TeletypeWriter eXchange) network<a1_0/>. TWX originally used the earlier <a2_0><b6_0>five-bit ITA2<b6_0/><a2_0/>, which was also used by the competing <b9_0>Telex teleprinter system<b9_0/>. <a3_0><b7_0>Bob Bemer<b7_0/><a3_0/> introduced features such as the escape sequence. His British colleague Hugh McGregor Ross helped to popularize this work –  according to Bemer, "so much so that the code that was to become ASCII was first called the <a4_0><b8_0>Bemer-Ross Code<b8_0/><a4_0/> in Europe". Because of his extensive work on ASCII, Bemer has been called "the father of ASCII."
